title: Predicting Ranks with Machine Learning : An Intro
content:
Have you ever wondered if it’s possible to predict someone’s rank before the results are even announced? Whether in academics, sports, or even gaming, ranks are everywhere—and they often decide opportunities, rewards, and recognition.

That curiosity is exactly what inspired me to start this project. I wanted to see how far machine learning could go in estimating ranks based on past performance data.

The concept is pretty straightforward:

📥 Input: A dataset with performance-related features (scores, activities, consistency, etc.).

⚙️ Process: A machine learning model analyzes patterns and relationships in the data.

📊 Output: A predicted rank that shows where someone might stand.

Why is this exciting? Because the project doesn’t just spit out numbers—it also highlights the key factors that matter most for performance. This makes it useful not just for prediction, but also for understanding why someone ranks where they do.

This article is the first part of a series where I’ll share the entire journey: from data preparation, to building the model, to interpreting results. If you’re curious about how machine learning can turn raw numbers into meaningful insights, stick around—there’s plenty to explore!

title: Predictiong Ranks with Machine Learning : Preparing Dataset
content:
Before any machine learning magic can happen, the most important step is understanding and cleaning the data. A model is only as good as the data it learns from—so this stage sets the foundation for everything else.

🔍 The Dataset

For this project, I used a structured dataset (sourced from Kaggle)  that contains features related to individual performance. In this case Each row represents a person, and each column describes something about them—for example:

Exam or test scores

Participation/attendance metrics

Performance in certain activities

Final outcome (rank/position)

This rank column is what we want to predict.

🧹 Preprocessing Steps

Raw data almost always needs some work before it’s ready for machine learning. Here’s what I did:

Cleaning Missing Values

Some rows had incomplete information. I either filled them with reasonable estimates (like averages) or removed them if too much data was missing.

Renaming and Standardizing Columns

To avoid confusion later, I made sure column names were consistent and easy to read.

Feature Selection

Not every column in the dataset helps with prediction. I selected the most relevant features that likely influence rank.

Encoding and Normalization

If there were any categorical variables (like “yes/no” fields), I converted them into numbers so the model could understand them.

I also scaled numerical values so that features with large ranges didn’t overpower smaller ones.

💡 Why This Matters

Preprocessing might feel less exciting than model training, but it’s absolutely critical. If the data is messy or poorly prepared, even the best machine learning model will struggle. By making the dataset clean and structured, we give the model the best chance to learn meaningful patterns.
